instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1398: What is A1398? A1398 is a model number for a 15 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Mid 2015, Mid 2012, Early 2013, Late 2013, Mid 2014 with EMC 2909, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00138, 820-00163, 820-00426, 820-3332, 820-3662, 820-3787..
definitions.PPVCORE_GPU: What is PPVCORE_GPU? This is the main power rail for the GPU. This is required for the GPU to turn on so you can get image on the display. .
definitions.U8900: What is U8900? This chip creates the GPU power rails on the 820-3332 board to the 2012 and early 2013 15‚Äù Retina Macbook Pros. It becomes desoldered and is the cause of no video and kernel panics/crashes in that model most of the time..
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .

threads.title: Macbook Pro Retina <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPVCORE_GPU</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Hi:
Im having an issue with a A820-3332 motherboard with <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> at 2.8V instead of 12.6V No chime, no fan spin one wire-circuit working with green light on MagSafe.
On scouting, I find this may be perhaps because of PPV removing <CHIP>U8900</CHIP> (62882), the <SIGNAL>PPVCORE_GPU</SIGNAL> shows 18 ohms to ground!

Please advise where to start...

threads.title: Macbook Pro Retina <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPVCORE_GPU</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Did you power up the board in such condition???
You've left <TRANSISTOR>Q8930</TRANSISTOR> with Gate pins floating on air.
GPU could be fried now, if you did that.

18 ohms looks good there.
Change <TRANSISTOR>Q8930</TRANSISTOR> and pray...

threads.title: Macbook Pro Retina <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPVCORE_GPU</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Aaaah! My Bad. Though I just checked, removing Fuse 7040 and 7041 shows 12.5V on pins 1 of the fuses. meaning something after the fuses is pulling <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> town to 2.5V. Hope this didn't fry the <TRANSISTOR>Q8930</TRANSISTOR>!

threads.title: Macbook Pro Retina <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPVCORE_GPU</SIGNAL>
threads.message: If pin 2 of F7040/41 shows 18 ohms, <TRANSISTOR>Q8930</TRANSISTOR> is shorted!

threads.title: Macbook Pro Retina <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPVCORE_GPU</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Removed <TRANSISTOR>Q8930</TRANSISTOR>. Fan spin and system chimes - though the original issue of eDP remains

to give a background, I had to remove the <CHIP>U8900</CHIP> as pin 39 was perhaps shorted to pin 40 though the embedded LCD worked. After replacing <CHIP>U8900</CHIP> the display disappeared. I again removed it.
then suddenly the issue you highlighted of <TRANSISTOR>Q8930</TRANSISTOR> shorting happened. Now, is there a way of ascertaining if 62882 is working properly and whats the probability of my GPU having fried....

Kindly advise on checking 62882 and probability of GPU dying with your experience.

threads.title: Macbook Pro Retina <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPVCORE_GPU</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Did you finally power up the board without <CHIP>U8900</CHIP>, despite of my advice???

If GPU coils show 18 ohms, you can still have a chance.
May need to change <TRANSISTOR>Q8930</TRANSISTOR> and <CHIP>U8900</CHIP> at same time.

threads.title: Macbook Pro Retina <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPVCORE_GPU</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Alas it was powered up before I posted when the <TRANSISTOR>Q8930</TRANSISTOR> was shorted....
18Ohm was Fuse F7040/41 to ground PRIOR to removal of the <TRANSISTOR>Q8930</TRANSISTOR>.
Have ordered the <TRANSISTOR>Q8930</TRANSISTOR> at Mauser so will take a few days. 

At the moment after removing <TRANSISTOR>Q8930</TRANSISTOR> and replacing the 62882 I did power up with GPU and CPU both warming up. Fan n Chime OK.

"If GPU coils show 18 ohms, you can still have a chance" Please give me  parameter and location to measure.

threads.title: Macbook Pro Retina <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPVCORE_GPU</SIGNAL>
threads.message: L8930 to ground does show 18 ohms!

threads.title: Macbook Pro Retina <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPVCORE_GPU</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Please advise if I also need to replace <TRANSISTOR>Q8961</TRANSISTOR>/31 649135PBF along with the <TRANSISTOR>Q8930</TRANSISTOR>. If so, as the 649135PBF is getting hard to find, a reference source will be highly appreciated.

threads.title: Macbook Pro Retina <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPVCORE_GPU</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
In THEORY, you should change <TRANSISTOR>Q8931</TRANSISTOR>/61 and <CHIP>U8900</CHIP> too.
Usually not needed, but you should know how to properly check that area, to ensure none of them is bad.
You can change them with MOSFETs from other (high current) CPU/GPU power supply.
But do NOT mix high/low-side MOSFETs; low-side MOSFETs require embedded Schottky diode!

threads.title: Macbook Pro Retina <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPVCORE_GPU</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Is there a way to check if the <TRANSISTOR>Q8931</TRANSISTOR>/61 are good by on-board diode mode voltage or normal resistance checks? 
kindly advise on this as finding replacement equivalents introduces another variable in the equation of an already complicated scenario of GPU/<TRANSISTOR>Q8930</TRANSISTOR>/62882

threads.title: Macbook Pro Retina <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPVCORE_GPU</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
If 18 ohms at GPU coils, probably low-side MOSFETs are good.
But you can remove them and measure out of board...

threads.title: Macbook Pro Retina <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPVCORE_GPU</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Thanks much.

threads.title: Macbook Pro Retina <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPVCORE_GPU</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
As stated, fans spinned, system chimed with <TRANSISTOR>Q8930</TRANSISTOR> removed. However, Replacing <TRANSISTOR>Q8930</TRANSISTOR> as well as 62882 and powering the board with MagSafe results in F7040/41 voltage dropping to 3.2V (resultantly no fan spin/ chime anymore) with coil showing a  <SIGNAL>PPVCORE_GPU</SIGNAL> voltage of 0.97 and <TRANSISTOR>Q8930</TRANSISTOR> heating abnormally. Removing <TRANSISTOR>Q8930</TRANSISTOR> restores fan spin and chime.

Please advise.

threads.title: Macbook Pro Retina <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPVCORE_GPU</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
STOP to power up a board after changing something, without checking for other problems.
If you find something burnt, think about a reason; try to eliminate the problem first.
There are some other components around <CHIP>U8900</CHIP>, <TRANSISTOR>Q8930</TRANSISTOR>; especially bootstrap R/C network.
ALWAYS check good continuity between MOSFETs Gate and controller chip.

threads.title: Macbook Pro Retina <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPVCORE_GPU</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
R/C Components check OK around the 62882 and <TRANSISTOR>Q8930</TRANSISTOR>.
Request  you to point me to  the specific  test points. Further, <SIGNAL>PPVCORE_GPU</SIGNAL> is 0.97V when <TRANSISTOR>Q8930</TRANSISTOR> heats up. 

Is there a possibility of the GPU (despite showing 16-18 ohms at coil) being somehow internally shorting leading to a virtual overdrive of the <TRANSISTOR>Q8930</TRANSISTOR> causing it to heat up abnormally and causing the F7040 voltage to drop to 3.2V, in which case replacing the GPU may be the only option unless suggested otherwise.

threads.title: Macbook Pro Retina <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPVCORE_GPU</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Very strange to get different <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> and GPU core voltage, if <TRANSISTOR>Q8930</TRANSISTOR> is shorted.
Ussually same voltage should be on both rails.

Your GPU is probably dead, after such torture...

threads.title: Macbook Pro Retina <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPVCORE_GPU</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Will replace GPU and update asap.

threads.title: Macbook Pro Retina <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPVCORE_GPU</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
GPU and <TRANSISTOR>Q8930</TRANSISTOR> replaced. Coil resistance drops to 5.6 Ohms. System boots. No excessive heating of any component but still no vcore GPU and hence no eDP image. 
please advise on further diagnosis.

threads.title: Macbook Pro Retina <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPVCORE_GPU</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Hi! Having changed <CHIP>U8900</CHIP> and it?s related RC components, replaces <TRANSISTOR>Q8930</TRANSISTOR> I have PPVCore as 1.05 which drops to 0.89 on fan spin (GPU has been removed to troubleshoot for now). 
HOWEVER , GPU FB Supply and GPU 1V05 Supply remain 0V on fanspin with GPU removed. 

My question is, are the supply levels OK without GPU and if I need to further troubleshoot the power units before I get the GPU in place.
